revision.text:
{{Merge from |Church music|discuss=Talk:Liturgical_music#Merge_with_Church_music|date=May 2017}} {{Christian culture}} '''Liturgical music''' originated as a part of [[religious]] [[ceremony]], and includes a number of traditions, both ancient and modern. Liturgical music is well known as a part of [[Catholic Mass]], the [[Anglican]] [[Holy Communion]] service (or [[Eucharist]]) and [[Evensong]], the [[Lutheran]] [[Divine Service (Lutheran)|Divine Service]], the [[Orthodox Christianity|Orthodox]] [[liturgy]] and other Christian services including the [[Liturgy of the Hours|Divine Office]]. Such ceremonial music in the Judeo-Christian tradition can be traced back to both the [[Temple in Jerusalem]] and [[synagogue]] worship of the [[Hebrews]].
The qualities that create the distinctive character of liturgical music are based on the notion that liturgical music is conceived and composed according to the norms and needs of the various historic [[liturgy|liturgies]] of particular [[Religious denomination|denomination]]s.
==Roman Catholic church music== [[File:F. 13r. Sherbrooke Missal.jpg|thumb|left|Musical notation in a 14th-century English Missal]] [[File:Catedral de la Natividad de Nuestra Señora de Baeza-Salterio-20110918-09728.jpg|thumb|Two pages of a psalter in Baeza Cathedral]] [[File:Monteverdi Missa da cappella a sei voci Kyrie.pdf|thumb|Monteverdi's ''Missa da cappella a sei voci; Kyrie'']] The interest taken by the Catholic Church in music is shown not only by practitioners, but also by numerous enactments and regulations calculated to foster music worthy of Divine service.<ref name="Gietmann1911">{{Catholic| title = Ecclesiastical Music | last = Gietmann | first = Gerhard | volume = 10 | year = 1911 | accessdate = 2007-05-17 | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/10648a.htm | inline = 1}}</ref> Contemporary [[Catholic]] official church policy is expressed in the documents of the [[Second Vatican Council]] ''[[Sacrosanctum Concilium]]'', the Constitution on the Sacred Liturgy promulgated by [[Pope Paul VI]] on December 4, 1963 (items 112–121); and most particularly ''[[Musicam sacram]]'', the Instruction on Music In The Liturgy from the Sacred Congregation for Rites, on March 5, 1967.
While there have been historic disputes within the church where elaborate music has been under criticism, there are many period works by Orlandus de [[Lassus]], [[Gregorio Allegri|Allegri]], [[Tomás Luis de Victoria|Vittoria]], where the most elaborate means of expression are employed in liturgical music, but which, nevertheless, conform to every liturgical requirement while seeming to be spontaneous outpourings of adoring hearts (cf. [[counterpoint|contrapuntal]] or [[polyphonic music]]). Besides [[plain chant]] and the polyphonic style, the Catholic Church also permits [[homophonic]] or figured compositions with or without instrumental accompaniment, written either in [[ecclesiastical]] [[Musical mode|modes]], or the modern major or minor keys. [[Gregorian chant]] is warmly recommended by the Catholic Church, as both polyphonic music and modern unison music for the assembly.<ref name="Gietmann1911"/>
Prior to the [[Second Vatican Council]], according to the [[motu proprio]] of Pius X (November 22, 1903), the following were the general guiding principles of the Church: "Sacred music should possess, in the highest degree, the qualities proper to the liturgy, or more precisely, sanctity and purity of form from which its other character of universality spontaneously springs. It must be holy, and must therefore exclude all profanity, not only from itself but also from the manner in which it is presented by those who execute it. It must be true art, for otherwise it cannot exercise on the minds of the hearers that influence which the Church meditates when she welcomes into her liturgy the art of music. But it must also be universal, in the sense that, while every nation is permitted to admit into its ecclesiastical compositions those special forms which may be said to constitute its native music, still these forms must be subordinated in such a manner to the general characteristics of sacred music, that no one of any nation may receive an impression other than good on hearing them.".<ref name="Gietmann1911"/> This was expanded upon by Pope [[Pius XII]] in his motu proprio ''[[Musicae sacrae]]''.<ref>''[http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xii/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-xii_enc_25121955_musicae-sacrae_en.html Musicae sacrae]''</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Sacred Christian music}} * [[Liturgy]] * [[Ephrem the Syrian]] * [[Contemporary Catholic liturgical music]] * [[Church music]] * [[Christian music]] * [[Religious music]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book|last=Wilson-Dickson|first=Andrew|title=The Story of Christian Music: An Illustrated Guide to All the Major Traditions of Music in Worship|year=2003|publisher=Lion|location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-7459-5119-5}}
==External links== {{commons category|Church music}} * [http://www.churchmusic.org.uk/ Anglican church music] * [http://www.antiochian.org/music Antiochian Orthodox liturgical music] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070528080714/http://www.acrod.org/music.html Carpatho Rusyn Liturgical Music] * [http://www.saintmeinrad.org/the-monastery/liturgical-music/ Catholic liturgical music at St Meinrad Archabbey] * [http://www.smithcreekmusic.com/Hymnology/Jewish.Hymnody/Jewish.Liturgical.Music.html Jewish liturgical music] * [http://www.lds.org/churchmusic/ Latter Day Saint church music] * [http://www.musicasacra.com/ The Church Music Association of America] * [http://www.catholic.net/rcc/Periodicals/Homiletic/2000-07/miller.html Pope Benedict XVI on liturgical music] * [http://www.rscm.com The Royal School of Church Music] * [http://www.syriacmusic.com/ Syriac church music]

page.title: National Museum of Women in the Arts

revision.text:
{{about|the museum in Washington, D.C.|other uses|NMWA (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Masonic Temple | nrhp_type = | image = National Museum of Women in the Arts.JPG | caption = National Museum of Women in the Arts | location= 1250 New York Ave NW, [[Washington, District of Columbia]] | coordinates = {{coord|38|54|0|N|77|1|46|W|region:US-DC_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = United States Washington, D.C. central#USA | built = 1903 | architect = [[Waddy Butler Wood|Wood, Donn & Deming]] | architecture = Classical Revival | added = February 18, 1987 | area = {{convert|0.3|acre}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 86002920<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} The '''National Museum of Women in the Arts''' (NMWA), located in [[Washington, D.C.]], is "the only major [[museum]] in the world solely dedicated" to celebrating women's achievements in the visual, performing, and literary arts.<ref name="about">{{cite web|url=http://www.nmwa.org/about|title=About|publisher= National Museum of Women in the Arts|accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref> NMWA was incorporated in 1981 by Wallace and [[Wilhelmina Holladay]]. Since opening its doors in 1987,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nmwa.org/about/our-history|title=Our History - National Museum of Women in the Arts|website=nmwa.org|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> the museum has acquired a collection of more than 4,500 paintings, sculptures, works on paper, and decorative art. Highlights of the collection include works by [[Mary Cassatt]], [[Frida Kahlo]], and [[Élisabeth Louise Vigée-Le Brun]]. The museum occupies the old [[Masonic Temple (Washington, D.C.)|Masonic Temple]], a building listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places.
==History== The museum was founded to reform traditional histories of art. It is dedicated to discovering and making known women artists who have been overlooked or unacknowledged, and assuring the place of women in contemporary art. The museum's founder, Wilhelmina Cole Holladay, and her husband Wallace F. Holladay began collecting art in the 1960s, just as scholars were beginning to discuss the under-representation of women in museum collections and major art exhibitions. Impressed by a 17th-century Flemish still life painting by [[Clara Peeters]] that they saw in Europe, they sought out information on Peeters and found that the definitive art history texts referenced neither her nor any other woman artist. They became committed to collecting artwork by women and eventually to creating a museum and research center.
The National Museum of Women in the Arts was incorporated in December 1981 as a private, non-profit museum, and the Holladay donation became the core of the institution's permanent collection. After purchasing and extensively renovating a former Masonic Temple, NMWA opened in April 1987 with the inaugural exhibition American Women Artists, 1830–1930. To underscore its commitment to increasing the attention given to women in all disciplines, NMWA commissioned Pulitzer Prize-winning composer [[Ellen Taaffe Zwilich]] to write ''Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra'' inspired by five paintings from the permanent collection, for an opening concert. In November 1997, the Elisabeth A. Kasser Wing was opened, adding two new galleries, a larger museum shop, and a reception room. Currently, Director Susan Fisher Sterling heads a staff of more than 30 people.
===Building=== {{Main|Masonic Temple (Washington, D.C.)}} In 1983, NMWA purchased a landmark {{convert|78810|sqft}} former Masonic temple in the Renaissance Revival style to house its works. After extensive renovations that included the addition of the two dramatic marble stairways linking the first floor and mezzanine, the museum opened to the public on April 7, 1987. The Elizabeth A. Kasser Wing opened November 8, 1997 making the entire facility {{convert|84110|sqft}}. [[File:NMWA - interior.jpg|thumb|left|Interior of the main floor]]
===Wilhelmina Cole Holladay=== {{main|Wilhelmina Cole Holladay}} [[Wilhelmina Cole Holladay]] is the founder and chair of the Board of the National Museum of Women in the Arts. Since her discovery that women artists have historically been omitted from collegiate art history texts, Wilhelmina Cole Holladay has made it her mission to bring to the forefront the accomplishments of women through collecting, exhibiting and researching women artists of all nationalities and time periods.
Holladay created individual committees of over 1,000 volunteers from 27 states and 7 countries, to give educational opportunities to children through collaborations with schools and other community groups (e.g. [[Girl Scouts of the USA]]), as well as provided opportunities for adults to participate and encourage art in local communities across the globe.
Wilhelmina Cole Holladay's interest in art was sparked as a student at [[Elmira College]] in New York, where she studied art history, followed by graduate work at the [[University of Paris]]. She is listed in ''[[Who's Who of American Women]]'', ''[[Who's Who in American Art]]'', ''[[Who's Who in the World]]'', and she holds many honorary degrees and achievement awards for her work in the arts community. In 2006 she received the [[National Medal of Arts]] from the United States and the ''[[Légion d'honneur]]'' from the French government. In 2007 Holladay received the Gold Medal for the Arts from the [[National Arts Club]] in New York City.
===New York Avenue Sculpture Project=== {{see also|Les Trois Grâces|Nana on a Dolphin}} By 2015, a selection of sculptures will be installed along New York Avenue from 13th Street to 9th Street, in the heart of [[Mount Vernon Square]]. The museums efforts are in part to bring "character" to an area where "there is a lot of good stuff going on," due to revitalization programs in the neighborhood.
[[Niki de Saint Phalle]]'s works, four in total, were the first in a series of installations.<ref name="Trescott1">{{cite news | author=Jacqueline Trescott | title=National Museum of Women in the Arts to turn D.C. corridor into sculpture alley | work=Style | publisher=The Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/23/AR2010022304712.html | accessdate= 8 Feb 2011 | date=February 24, 2010}}</ref> The museums installation of de Saint Phalle's iconic pop art works are meant to be contrasting to the traditional sculpture that graces the streets and squares of Washington. All five major median strips will eventually be made into "sculpture islands," as described by National Museum of Women in the Art's director [[Susan Fisher Sterling]]. Another inspiration for the project comes from the lack of innovative contemporary art in Washington, encouraging the evolution of an area that is in need of becoming hip and vibrant.<ref name="Trescott1"/> The second artist to be featured, whose works are on display March 8, 2012 – March 9, 2014, was [[Chakaia Booker]].<ref>{{cite blog|url=http://womeninthearts.wordpress.com/2012/03/07/chakaia-booker-evocative-dynamic-works-in-the-new-york-avenue-sculpture-project/|date=March 7, 2012|title=Chakaia Booker: Evocative, Dynamic Works in the New York Avenue Sculpture Project|author=Orin Zahra|publisher=National Museum of Women in the Arts}}</ref>
The project has been sponsored by Medda Gudelsky, the D.C. Downtown B.I.D., the Philip L. Graham Fund, the Homer and Martha Gudelsky Family Foundation, members of the museum, the D.C. Department of Transportation, among others.<ref name="Pressphalle">{{cite web | author=Michelle Cragle | year=2010 | title=National Museum of Women in the Arts Announces Sculpture Project | work=Press Center | publisher=Niki Charitable Art Foundation | url=http://nikidesaintphalle.org/press/20100224_nmwa | accessdate=8 Feb 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306070929/http://nikidesaintphalle.org/press/20100224_nmwa | archivedate=2010-03-06 | df= }}</ref>
These works will remain up for one year, before being returned to the artists foundation.<ref name="Gopnik1">{{cite news | author=Blake Gopnik | title=Sculptures add color to New York Avenue, but are they art? | work=Style | publisher=The Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/27/AR2010042703104.html | accessdate= 8 Feb 2011 | date=April 28, 2010}}</ref>
==Collection== [[File:Young Girl with a Sheaf.jpg|thumb|[[Camille Claudel]], ''Young Girl with a Sheaf'', ca. 1890]]
The collection currently contains more than 4,500 works in a variety of styles and media, spanning from the 16th century to present day. Among the earliest works is [[Lavinia Fontana]]’s Portrait of a Noblewoman, ca. 1580. There are also a number of special collections, including 18th century botanical prints, works by British and Irish women silversmiths from the 17th–19th centuries,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nmwa.org/collection/|title=Collection Highlights - National Museum of Women in the Arts|website=nmwa.org|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> and more than 1,000 unique and limited edition artists’ books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmwa.org/library/artistbook.asp|title=Library & Archives - National Museum of Women in the Arts|website=www.nmwa.org|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref>
Nearly 1,000 artists are represented, including [[Magdalena Abakanowicz]], [[Lynda Benglis]], [[Rosa Bonheur]], [[Chakaia Booker]], [[Louise Bourgeois]], [[Lola Alvarez Bravo]], [[Rosalba Carriera]], [[Mary Cassatt]], [[Elizabeth Catlett]], [[Judy Chicago]], [[Camille Claudel]], [[Louisa Courtauld]], [[Petah Coyne]], [[Louise Dahl-Wolfe]], [[Elaine de Kooning]], [[Lesley Dill]], [[Helen Frankenthaler]], [[Sonia Gechtoff]], [[Marguerite Gérard]], [[Nan Goldin]], [[Nancy Graves]], [[Grace Hartigan]], [[Frida Kahlo]], [[Angelica Kauffman]], [[Käthe Kollwitz]], [[Lee Krasner]], [[Justine Kurland]], [[Bettye Lane]], [[Marie Laurencin]], [[Hung Liu]], [[Judith Leyster]], [[Maria Martinez]], [[Maria Sibylla Merian]], [[Joan Mitchell]], [[Gabriele Münter]], [[Elizabeth Murray (artist)|Elizabeth Murray]], [[Alice Neel]], [[Louise Nevelson]], [[Sarah Miriam Peale]], [[Clara Peeters]], [[Lilla Cabot Perry]], [[Jaune Quick-to-See Smith]], [[Rachel Ruysch]], [[Elisabetta Sirani]], [[Joan Snyder]], [[Lilly Martin Spencer]], [[Alma Thomas]], [[Suzanne Valadon]], and [[Louise Élisabeth Vigée Le Brun|Élisabeth-Louise Vigée-Le Brun]].
== Betty Boyd Dettre Library and Research Center == The Betty Boyd Dettre Library and Research Center (LRC) provides researchers with information about women visual artists from all time periods and nationalities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmwa.org/learn/library-archives|title=Library & Archives - National Museum of Women in the Arts|website=www.nmwa.org|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> It is open to scholars, students, researchers, curators, museum professionals, and the general public. The LRC collection includes 18,500 volumes of books and exhibition catalogues, 50 periodical titles, and research files on 18,000 individual women artists. These files include resumes, correspondence, reproductions, articles, and other ephemeral materials. The Arts and Entertainment Network Media Library holds approximately 500 videos, DVDs, audio tapes, and other audiovisual materials, including examples of video art, interviews with women artists, documentaries, and films directed by women.
Also available to researchers are The Nelleke Nix and Marianne Huber Collection: The Frida Kahlo Papers consists of more than 360 unpublished letters, postcards, notes, clippings, printed matter, and drawings relating to the artist's life and work.
In spring 2007, the LRC launched "[[Clara database|Clara: Database of Women Artists]]," a user-friendly searchable interface for biographic information on close to 18,000 historic and contemporary women artists from around the world. Since integrated within the NMWA web site, Clara has been decommissioned and is in the process of being moved.
==Exhibitions== Beginning in 1987 with ''American Women Artists, 1830–1930'', NMWA has presented more than 200 exhibitions. A selection of the most prominent exhibitions includes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nmwa.org/exhibition/|title=Exhibitions - National Museum of Women in the Arts|website=nmwa.org|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Exhibition History (1987–2013)|url=http://www.nmwa.org/sites/default/files/shared/nmwa_exhibition_history_2013_2.pdf|publisher=National Museum of Women in the Arts|accessdate=29 March 2013}}</ref>
* ''[[Loïs Mailou Jones]]: A Life in Vibrant Color'' (Oct. 9, 2010–Jan. 9, 2011) * ''Royalists to Romantics: Women Artists from the Louvre, Versailles, and Other French National Collections'' (Feb. 24–Jul. 29 2012) * ''An Imperial Collection: Women Artists from the [[State Hermitage Museum]]'' (Feb. 14, 2003–June 18, 2003) * ''Women Who Rock: Vision, Passion, Power'' (Sep. 7, 2012–Jan. 6, 2013) * ''Places of Their Own: [[Emily Carr]], [[Georgia O'Keeffe]], and [[Frida Kahlo]]'' (Feb. 8, 2002–May 12, 2002) * ''The Magic of [[Remedios Varo]]'' (Feb. 10, 2000-May 29, 2000) * ''[[Julie Taymor]]: Playing With Fire'' (Nov. 16, 2000–Feb. 4, 2001) * ''[[WACK! Art and the Feminist Revolution]]'' (Sep. 21, 2007–Dec. 16, 2007) * ''Dreaming Their Way: Australian Aboriginal Women'' (Jun. 30, 2006–Sep. 24, 2006)
==Public programs== NMWA hosts educational programs for all age groups to teach the public about the artistic accomplishments of women. Programs include monthly Community Days<ref>[http://www.nmwa.org/visit/visitor-information Visitor information] from NMWA</ref> with free museum admission, and Role Model Workshops that connect teenagers with accomplished women working in the art world. Member days include curator- and artist-led tours. The Education Department is also involved in various outreach programs to area educators. For example, the 2010 "Teachers Connect" program was designed around the promotion of NMWA's Art, Books, and Creativity curriculum.
The free Shenson Chamber Music Concerts support the museum's mission of recognizing women in all areas of the arts by featuring woman musicians throughout the year. Past performers include the [[Ahn Trio]], Arianna and Eugenia Zuckerman, [[Ingrid Fliter]], Sharon Ibsin and [[Rachel Barton Pine]]. NMWA's literary programs showcase women writers by bringing in authors such as Susan Vreeland, [[Lisa See]], [[Maxine Hong Kingston]], [[Naomi Shihab Nye]], [[Joyce Carol Oates]], and [[Mireille Guiliano]]. In addition, NMWA has offered film screenings of works by respected women directors and screenwriters including [[Maya Angelou]], [[Barbara Hammer]], [[Cheryl Dunye]], Eva López Sánchez, [[Miranda July]], Bette Gordon, and [[Julie Taymor]].
==Operations== The museum is located at 1250 [[New York Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|New York Avenue]] and [[H Street]] N.W. The closest [[Washington Metro]] stations are [[Metro Center (Washington Metro)|Metro Center]] or [[McPherson Square]] stations. The museum is open Monday–Saturday 10 a.m.–5 p.m. and Sundays noon–5 p.m. Admission is $10 for adults, $8 for students and visitors 65 and over, and free for members and visitors 18 and under. Admission is free to all on the first Sunday of every month. The NMWA Museum Shop is open the same hours at the Museum.
==See also== * [[House of the Temple]], another Masonic Temple building on 16th Street, nearby * [[New Hall Art Collection]] * [[Women artists]]

'''Nature printing''' is a printing process, developed in the 18th century, that uses the plants, animals, rocks and other natural subjects to produce an image. The subject undergoes several stages to give a direct impression onto materials such as lead, gum, and photographic plates, which are then used in the printing process.
[[Image:Benjamin Franklin nature printed currency sheet 1779.jpg|thumb|[[Benjamin Franklin]]'s nature printed currency (1779)]] While some sources state that [[Benjamin Franklin]] invented nature printing from leaf casts, using a copper plate press, in 1737 to thwart counterfeiters of paper money bills,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.philadelphiafed.org/education/teachers/publications/intersections/2007/spring/ |title = Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia Releases New Benjamin Franklin Publication |accessdate = 2010-07-26 |author = FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF PHILADELPHIA |year = 2007 |publisher = FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF PHILADELPHIA |quote = In 1737 Franklin invented the art of nature printing from leaf casts, using a copper plate press, for transferring a sage leaf image onto the back of paper money bills, a technique intended to thwart counterfeiters.}}</ref> other sources also report Franklin's friend, Philadelphia naturalist [[Joseph Breintnall]], to have made contact nature prints from leaves about 1730.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://hq.abaa.org/books/antiquarian/news_fly?code=22 |title = Benjamin Franklin's Job Printing |accessdate = 2010-07-26 |author = Georgia B. Barnhill |publisher = ABAA (This article first appeared in Ephemera News or The Ephemera Journal, publications of The Ephemera Society of America, Inc.) |quote = The [leaf printing] technique was not well known at the time, although the Philadelphia naturalist Joseph Breintnall made contact nature prints from leaves about 1730.}}</ref> Together they sent nature prints which were printed directly from inked leaves to English naturalists.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.librarycompany.org/bfwriter/job.htm |title = Benjamin Franklin: Writer and Printer |accessdate = 2010-07-26 |author = James N. Green and Peter Stallybrass |year = 2006 |publisher = The Library Company of Philadelphia |quote = Franklin probably got the idea of printing images of leaves on paper money from making these nature prints, which he and Breintnall sent to English naturalists. They were printed directly from inked leaves, which were placed inside a folded sheet of paper and run through the press. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101001183000/http://www.librarycompany.org/bfwriter/job.htm |archivedate = 2010-10-01 |df = }}</ref>
[[Image:Nature print (Bradbury).jpg|thumb|Plate from ''The Nature-printed British Seaweeds'', (1859-60).]]
Another person attributed with the invention of the process, [[:de:Naturselbstdruck|''Naturselbstdruck'']], is [[Alois Auer]]; the first publication, of instructions for the process, was by this Austrian printer in ''The Discovery of the Natural Printing Process: an Invention ...'' Vienna, 1853. This was written in four languages by the author. He shows the use of plants, a fossil fish, and lace impressed by roller onto a lead plate, this is hand coloured and transferred to the final print. [[Image:Nature print, Alois Auer.jpg|thumb|240px]] Many others botanical and natural history illustrations had attempted to use techniques that were a 'shorthand', or for a type of accuracy, in the representation of subjects. Another printer, the Englishman [[Henry Bradbury]], immediately used Auer's 'nature printing' process to publish work of his own. These included two major botanical works; *''[[The Ferns of Great Britain and Ireland]]'', [[Thomas Moore (botanist)|Moore, Thomas]].<ref>The Ferns of Great Britain and Ireland; Edited by [[John Lindley]]. Nature-printed by Henry Bradbury. London: Bradbury & Evans, 1857.</ref>(1857) and the rendition of these species was readily adapted to the process; the two dimensional print would reveal form and detail for the identification of species. *''The Nature-Printed British Sea-Weeds'', W.G. Johnstone & A. Croall. 1859-60.<ref>Johnstone, William Grosart & Alexander Croall. ''The Nature-Printed British Sea-Weeds: A History, accompanied by figures and dissections, of the algæ of the British Isles''. Four volumes. London: Bradbury & Evans, 1859-60. Text available on Google books [https://books.google.com/books?id=3yaTjgEACAAJ&dq=nature+printed+british+sea+weeds&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjy9_TitsrKAhUH4D4KHTfFCl8Q6AEILzAD here].</ref>
[[Sherman Denton]] in his book ''As Nature Shows Them: Moths and Butterflies ...'' used the wings of the species he was describing by pressing them into the page itself. For this work he used over 50,000 insects.<ref name=Dentonc1900>{{cite book|last1=Denton|first1=Sherman Foote|title=As nature shows them : moths and butterflies of the United States, east of the Rocky Mountains : with over 400 photographic illustrations in the text and many transfers of species from life|page = vi|date=1900|publisher=J.B. Millet|location=Boston, U.S.A|url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/45790#page/11/mode/1up|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>
==Auer method== Auer's method can only be used with objects with tolerably flat surfaces, such as dried and pressed plants, embroidery and lace, and a few animals. The object is placed between a plate of steel and another of lead, both of which are smooth, and polished. They are then drawn through a pair of rollers under considerable pressure. When the plates are separated, it is found that a perfect impression of the object has been made in the leaden plate. This may be used directly as an engraved plate, but only if a very few impressions are wanted, for it is too soft to resist the action of printing presses for practical purposes. For larger numbers of images, a facsimile to be used as the printing plate is made in copper by the [[electrotyping|electrotype]] process.<ref>{{Cite NIE|wstitle=Nature Printing|year=1905}}</ref>
==Further reading== *Eric P. Newman, "Newly Discovered Franklin Invention: Nature Printing on Colonial and Continental Currency," The Numismatist (1964)
==References == {{Commons}} {{Reflist}} {{refbegin}} *{{cite web | url = http://www.lib.udel.edu/ud/spec/exhibits/color/natures.htm | title = Nature printing | accessdate = 2007-09-02 | author = Iris Snyder (Curator) | authorlink = | coauthors = | date = | year = | month = | work = Color printing in the nineteenth century | publisher = University of Delaware Library | quote = }} {{refend}}

[[File:Otesanekmonster.jpg|thumb|Artistic representation of ''Otesánek''.]] '''Otesánek''' is a [[Czech literature|Czech]] fairy tale created by [[Karel Jaromír Erben]] in the 19th century which tells the story of a fearsome and constantly hungry, living log of wood. In the story there are elements of narrative that are similar to more famous fairy tales such as [[The Adventures of Pinocchio]] and [[Little Red Riding Hood]]; despite this, the themes present in Otesánek appear nonetheless to be quite different from most other European fairy tales, with a particularly ambiguous [[moral]] which leaves a lot of room to subjective interpretation.
==Plot== The story begins with a couple that for a long time has been waiting for a child, which however does not seem to arrive. One day the husband finds in the nearby forest a log of wood (Otesánek) that strangely resembles a baby and decides to bring it home. To the joy of the couple, the wooden baby comes to life and asks to be fed. Initially the couple is enthusiastic that their wish of having a child has finally been granted, however the situation soon takes a turn for the worse as they find themselves having to deal with the insatiable appetite of the baby, who will keep growing and eating until he will start eating even people, including his parents. The log anticipates each meal with a nursery rhyme in which he lists every previous meal he has done. The story eventually concludes with the death of Otesánek at the hands of an elderly lady of the village who rips open his chest with a hoe, thus killing the monster and freeing all those who were eaten by him, including his parents.
==Film adaptation== The film ''[[Little Otik]]'', directed by [[Jan Švankmajer]], was released in 2000 and is greatly inspired by this fairly tale.
==External links== *{{cs icon}} [http://www.pohadky.unas.cz/ot.html Otesánek, fairy tale in Czech], www.pohadky.unas.cz *{{cs icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20130511142036/http://www.abatar.cz/pohadky/otesanek.htm Otesánek, fairy tale in Czech], www.abatar.cz
{{DEFAULTSORT:Otesanek}} [[Category:Fairy tales]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{refimprove|date=March 2009}} A '''parallel import''' is a non-[[counterfeit]] [[good (accounting)|product]] imported from another country without the permission of the [[intellectual property]] owner. Parallel imports are often referred to as [[grey market|grey product]] and are implicated in issues of [[international trade]], and [[intellectual property]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/thewto_e/glossary_e/parallel_imports_e.htm|title=WTO - Glossary - parallel imports|website=www.wto.org|accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
Parallel importing is based on concept of [[exhaustion of intellectual property rights]]: according to this concept, when the product is first launched on the market in a particular jurisdiction, parallel importation is authorized to all residents in the state in question. Some countries allow it but others do not.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inta.org/Advocacy/Pages/ParallelImportsGrayMarket.aspx|title=Parallel Imports/Gray Market|website=www.inta.org|accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
Parallel importing of pharmaceuticals reduces price of pharmaceuticals by introducing competition; [[TRIPS agreement]] in Article 6 states that this practice cannot be challenged under the WTO dispute settlement system and so is effectively a matter of national discretion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/trips_e/factsheet_pharm02_e.htm|title=WTO - Intellectual property (TRIPS) - fact sheet - pharmaceuticals - 2|website=www.wto.org|accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
The practice of parallel importing is often advocated in the case of software, music, printed texts and electronic products, and occurs for several reasons:
# Different versions of a product are produced for sale in different markets: the UK edition of [[Top Gear Magazine]] is officially sold in the UK, and [[Top Gear Australia (magazine)|Top Gear Australia]] is officially sold in Australia. However some unofficial distributors in [[Australia]] also sell the UK edition of Top Gear Magazine. # Companies, either the manufacturer or the distributor, set different [[price points]] for their products in different markets. Parallel importers ordinarily purchase products in one country at a price (P1) which is cheaper than the price at which they are sold in a second country (P2), import the products into the second country, and benefitting from [[arbitrage]], sell the products in that country at a price which is usually between P1 and P2. # Consumers who are able to obtain more competitively priced items and may be able to avoid local sales taxes, are placed on an even footing with consumers who have less access to overseas sales online.<ref>{{cite web|title=Your Question ANswered |url=https://www.alia.org.au/advocacy/copyright/your.ques.answered.html |accessdate=16 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515131714/http://www.alia.org.au/advocacy/copyright/your.ques.answered.html |archivedate=15 May 2013 }}</ref> # Some advocacy groups support parallel importing on the grounds of enhancing the free flow of information.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alia.org.au/advocacy/copyright/your.ques.answered.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825182748/http://www.alia.org.au/advocacy/copyright/your.ques.answered.html |archivedate=25 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==International approach== Parallel importing is regulated differently in different jurisdictions; there is no consistency in laws dealing with parallel imports between countries. Neither the [[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works|Berne Convention]] nor the [[Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property|Paris Convention]] explicitly prohibit parallel importation.
===Australia=== The Australian market is an example of a relatively small consumer market which does not benefit from the economies of scale and competition available in the larger global economies. Australia tends to have lower levels of competition in many industries and oligopolies are common in industries like banking, supermarkets, and mobile telecommunications.
Private Enterprise will use product segmentation strategies to legally maximise profit. This often includes varying the service levels, pricing and product features to improve so called "fit" to the local marketplace. However this segmentation may mean an identical products at often higher prices. This can be termed "Price Discrimination".<ref>{{cite web|title=Winning entry for the Kirby Cup 2012 {{!}} Saving the right to parallel import in a digital world|url=http://www.alrc.gov.au/winning-entry-kirby-cup-2012-saving-right-parallel-import-digital-world |date=22 Nov 2012 |accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> With the advent of the Internet, Australian consumers can readily compare prices globally and have been able to identify products exhibiting Price Discrimination, also known as the "[[Australia Tax]]".
In 1991, the Australian Government resolved to remove parallel import restrictions from a range of products except cars. It followed this up with legislation making it legal to source music and software CDs from overseas and import them into Australia. An Australian Productivity Commission report recommended in July 2009 that legislation be extended to legalise the parallel importing of books, with three years' notice for publishers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hudson|first1=Andrew|title=Australia: Productivity Commission Recommends Removal Of Parallel Import Protection For Books|url=http://www.mondaq.com/australia/article.asp?articleid=83242|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> The commission also recommended abolishing restrictions on parallel importing of cars.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Charlwood|first1=Sam|title=Cheaper second-hand imported cars a step closer|url=http://www.drive.com.au/motor-news/cheaper-secondhand-imported-cars-a-step-closer-20140214-32prt.html|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref>
Federal Court of Australia [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCAFC/2012/130.html decision] shows that parallel imported items with valid trademark are subject to [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/tma1995121/s123.html Section 123 of the Trade Mark Act].
Various Parliament of Australia committees have investigated allegations of Price Discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|title=House of Representatives Committees|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/parliamentary_business/committees/house_of_representatives_committees?url=ic/itpricing/subs.htm|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref>
===European Union/European Economic Area=== The [[European Union]] (and [[European Economic Area]]) requires the doctrine of international exhaustion to exist between member states (contracting states) but EU legislation for trade marks, design rights and copyright prohibits its application to goods put on the market outside the EU/EEA.
===Germany=== In [[Germany]], the [[Bundesgerichtshof]] has held that the [[exhaustion of rights|doctrine of international exhaustion]] governs parallel importation, subject to the EU rules above.
===Hong Kong=== In Hong Kong, parallel importation is permitted under both, the [[Trade Mark]] and (amended) [[Copyright]] Ordinance before The Copyright (Amendment) Ordinance 2007 came into force 6 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.gov.hk/en/category/lawandorder/071212/html/071212en08002.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-12-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214013629/http://www.news.gov.hk/en/category/lawandorder/071212/html/071212en08002.htm |archivedate=14 December 2007 |df=dmy-all }} Seven arrested for copyright infringement</ref>
===Japan=== [[Japan]]'s intellectual property rights law prohibits audiovisual articles marketed for export from being sold domestically, and such sale of "re-imported" CDs are illegal.
===United States=== In the [[United States]], legal precedent has established that parallel importation is legal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/523/135.html|title=FindLaw's United States Supreme Court case and opinions.|website=Findlaw|accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref> In the case of [[Kirtsaeng v. John Wiley & Sons, Inc.]], the US Supreme Court held that the [[first-sale doctrine]] applies to copies of a copyrighted work lawfully made abroad, thus permitting importation and resale of many product categories.
Moreover, Science, State, Justice, and Commerce, and Related Agencies, Appropriations Act of 2006 prohibits future FTAs from categorically disallowing the parallel import of patented products.<ref>Shayerah Ilias, Ian Fergusson, “Intellectual Property Rights and International Trade,” Congressional research Service, February 17, 2011</ref>
==Automobiles== {{mainarticle|Grey import vehicle}}
===United States=== The United States has unique automobile design legislation administered by the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]]. Certain car makers find the required modifications too expensive. This creates demand for [[grey import vehicles]], where certain models are modified for individual customers to meet these requirements, at a higher expense than if this were done by the original manufacturer on an [[assembly line]]. This procedure interferes with the marketing scheme of the manufacturer, who might plan to import a less powerful car and force consumers to accept it. The Imported Vehicle Safety Compliance Act of 1988 basically ended the gray market by requiring manufacturer certification of U.S.-bound cars.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Aaron|title=How To: Win the Car-Importing Game|url=http://blog.caranddriver.com/how-to-win-the-car-importing-game/|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref>
==Parallel-imported foodstuffs, etc.== Markets for parallel imports and locally made products sometimes exist alongside each other even though the parallel imports are markedly more expensive. This may be for various reasons, but is mostly observed in foodstuffs and toiletry.
Due to the nature of hotels, travellers often have little information on where to shop except in the immediate vicinity. Grocery shops opened to serve brand-name hotels often feature parallel-imported foodstuffs and toiletry to cater to travellers so that they can easily recognise the product they have been using at home.
Foodstuffs and toiletry made from different plants may vary in quality because different plants may use materials or reagents (such as water used for washing, food additives) from different sources, although they are usually subject to the same standards by internal QC or public health authorities. A person may be allergic to the foodstuff or toiletry made by some plants but not others.
To sum up, the major reasons for such a market are:
* Lack of information * Recognisability * Avoidance of risk due to products by different plants <!--Appreciated if someone could improve clarity-->
==Issues== A manifestation of the philosophical divide between those who support various intellectual property and [[Criticism of intellectual property|those who are critical of it]], is the divide over the legitimacy of parallel importation. Some believe that it benefits consumers by lowering prices and widening the selection and consumption of products available in the [[Market (economics)|market]], while others believe that it discourages intellectual property owners from investing in new and [[innovation|innovative]] products. Some also believe that parallel imports tend to facilitate [[copyright infringement]].
This tension essentially concerns the [[rights]] and [[duty|duties]] of a protected [[monopoly]]. Intellectual property rights allow the holder to sell at a price that is higher than the price one would pay in a [[competition|competitive market]], but by doing so the holder relinquishes sales to those who would be prepared to buy at a price between the monopoly price and the competitive price. The presence of parallel imports in the marketplace prevents the holder from exploiting the monopoly further by [[market segmentation]], i.e. by applying different prices to different consumers.
[[Consumer organisation]]s tend to support parallel importation as it offers consumers more choice and lower prices, provided that consumers retain equivalent legal protection to locally sourced products (e.g. in the form of [[warranty|warranties]] with international effect), and competition is not diminished.
However, such organisations also warn consumers of certain risks in using parallel-imported products. Although the products may have been made to comply with the laws and customs of their place of origin, these products or their use may not comply with those in places where they are used, or some of their functions may be rendered unusable or meaningless (which may needlessly drive up prices). Electronic devices, however, suffer less from this type of risk because newer models support more than one user language.
==Examples==
===Australia=== Importation of [[computer games]] and computer game hardware from [[Asia]] is a common practice for some wholesale and/or retail stockists. Many consumers now take advantage of on-line stores in [[Hong Kong]] and the [[United States]] to purchase computer games at or near half the cost of a retail purchase from the Australian RRP. Often the versions sold by the Asian retailers are manufactured in Australia to begin with. An example is [[Crysis]], which was available from Hong Kong on-line stores for approximately $50 AUD but whose retail cost in Australia was close to $100. Crysis was sold in Asia using identical versions of the game box and disc, right down to including Australian censor ratings on the box.
===Hong Kong=== {{See also|Parallel trading in Hong Kong}} Importation of [[Colgate (toothpaste)|Colgate]] [[toothpaste]] from [[Thailand]] into [[Hong Kong]]. The goods are bought in markets where the price is lower, and sold in markets where the price of the same goods is, for a variety of reasons, higher. Electronic goods like Apple's [[iPad]] are frequently imported in Hong Kong before they're official and resold to South-East Asian early adopters for a premium.
===New Zealand=== The practice exists of luxury [[automobile|car]] dealers in [[New Zealand]] buying [[Mercedes-Benz]] [[vehicle]]s in [[Malaysia]] at a low price, and importing the cars into New Zealand to sell at a price lower than the price offered by Mercedes Benz to New Zealand consumers.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} There are also many parallel import dealers of electronics hardware. Parallel importing is allowed in New Zealand and has resulted in a significant lowering of margins on many products. {{Citation needed|date=February 2016}}
===Poland=== There is an opinion, not scientifically proven, but very popular among people in Poland that "Western" washing powders are more effective in cleaning than Polish, because chemistry companies allegedly produce items of higher quality for Western Europe, not as good as for Poland. Because of that, there are companies and online stores importing Western chemistry supplies to Poland (for example from Germany), even if similar brands are available there.<ref>http://www.luna24.pl/produkty/proszki-do-prania,2</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pralinka.pl/Chemia-z-niemiec/niemiecki-proszek-do-prania/|title=Proszki do prania z Niemiec - niemiecka chemia pralinka.pl|first=Trol|last=InterMedia|website=www.pralinka.pl|accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
===Russian Federation=== <!-- according to the rg.ru article, external trade volume is 12 times that of internal trade --> According to [http://bablaw.livejournal.com/ Anatoliy Semyonov], trademark rights exhaustion turned national in 2002, and, as of April 2013, an act is being prepared that could make original goods imported without a permission of the producer officially "counterfeit" (by replacing things on which "a trademark is located illegally" with things "on which an illegally used trademark is located"). He notes that, according to the [[Criminal Code of Russia|Criminal Code]], illegal use of a trademark can be punished up to 6 years of imprisonment; and a similar article in the [[Offences Code of Russia|Offences Code]] makes goods with an illegal copy of a trademark subject to confiscation.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://rapsinews.ru/legislation_publication/20130402/266899025.html |title = Параллельный импорт: бизнес-омбудсмены выступили против корпораций |publisher = RAPSI ([[RIA Novosti]]) |date = 2 Apr 2013 |accessdate = 10 Apr 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.rg.ru/2013/04/09/tovari.html |author = Irina Fursova |title = Импорту параллельно |publisher = [[Rossiyskaya Gazeta]] |date = 9 Apr 2013 |accessdate = 10 Apr 2013 }}</ref>
===European Union=== Some [[PlayStation Portable|Sony PSP]] video game consoles were imported into the [[European Economic Area]] from Japan up to twelve months prior to the European launch. The unusual component of this example is that some importers were selling the console for a higher price than the intended EU price, taking advantage of the relative monopoly they enjoyed. After the release the console was commonly imported from the USA where it was retailed for much lower price.
Other example are smart phones, which are being imported from China, where an average device can be bought for about $100 while a similar device would be retailed for about 200€ in the EU.
==See also== * [[Counterfeit consumer goods]] * [[Exhaustion of rights]] * [[Grey market]] * [[Import scene]] * [[Importation right]] * [[Parallel importing in video games]] * [[Track and trace]]
==Bibliography== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080516005011/http://www.thegrayblog.com/ The Gray Blog] is a blog dedicated to parallel market legal issues. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100825182748/http://www.alia.org.au/advocacy/copyright/your.ques.answered.html Australian Library and Information Association - Statement on Parallel Importing] [https://www.dutchparalleltrading.com/ Statement on Parallel import and export, or parallel trade * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100123091847/http://www.pc.gov.au/projects/study/books/report Australian Productivity Commission 2009: "Restrictions on the Parallel Importation of Books"] - The Australian Productivity Commission report, released 14 July 2009, presented original research to advocate the removal of parallel import restrictions on books. * {{cite web |url = https://lwn.net/Articles/543616/ |title = Upholding the first sale doctrine
==References== <references />
{{Trademark law}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Parallel Import}} [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Import]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Portrait of Émile Zola''''' is a painting of [[Émile Zola]] by [[Édouard Manet]]. Manet submitted the portrait to the 1868 Salon. [[Image:Edouard Manet 049.jpg|thumb|right|220px]]
At this time Zola was known for his art criticism, and perhaps particularly as the writer of the novel [[Thérèse Raquin]]. This told the story of an adulterous affair between Thérèse, the wife of a clerk in a railway company, and a would-be painter named Laurent, whose work, rather like that of Zola's friend [[Paul Cézanne]], is denigrated by the critics.<ref>Ross King, ''The Judgment of Paris'', p. 223.</ref> In the eleventh chapter the milieu of Manet's [[Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe]] is evoked, in the murder scene, where Camille, the husband, goes out for the day with his wife and her lover to [[Saint-Ouen, Seine-Saint-Denis|Saint-Ouen]].
On the wall is a reproduction of Manet's ''[[Olympia (painting)|Olympia]]'', a controversial painting at the 1865 Salon but which Zola considered Manet's best work. "Behind it is an engraving from [[Diego Velázquez|Velazquez]]'s ''Bacchus'' indicating the taste for Spanish art shared by the painter and the writer. A Japanese print of a wrestler by [[Utagawa school|Utagawa Kuniaki II]] completes the décor." A Japanese screen on the left of the picture recalls the role that the Far East played in revolutionizing ideas on perspective and colour in European painting.<ref>[http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/works-in-focus/painting/commentaire_id/emile-zola-3060.html?tx_commentaire_pi1%5BpidLi%5D=509&tx_commentaire_pi1%5Bfrom%5D=841&cHash=97ca12b598 musee-orsay]</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/works-in-focus/painting/commentaire_id/emile-zola-3060.html?tx_commentaire_pi1%5BpidLi%5D=509&tx_commentaire_pi1%5Bfrom%5D=841&cHash=97ca12b598 musee-orsay]
{{Édouard Manet|state=expanded}} {{Émile Zola}}
<!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Paintings by Édouard Manet]] [[Category:Portraits of men|Zola]] [[Category:1868 paintings]] [[Category:19th-century portraits|Zola]] [[Category:Portraits by French artists|Zola]] [[Category:Books in art]]

revision.comment: /* History */ italics not needed, distinguihs between painting someone's portrait: "the portrait of X" and painting a painting called: "Portrait of X". This instance s the former.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Retrato_de_Juan_Pareja,_by_Diego_Velázquez.jpg | title=Portrait of Juan de Pareja | artist=[[Diego Velázquez]] | year=c. 1650 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=81.3 | width_metric=69.9 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] | city=New York City }} The '''''Portrait of Juan de Pareja''''' is a painting by Spanish artist [[Diego Velázquez]] of his assistant [[Juan de Pareja]], a notable painter in his own right, who was [[Slavery in Spain|enslaved]] and owned by Velázquez at the time the painting was completed. Velázquez painted the portrait in [[Rome]], while traveling in [[Italy]], in 1650. It is the earliest known [[Portrait painting#Baroque and Rococo|portrait]] of a Spanish man of African descent.<ref>{{Cite book|url=|title=The Image of the Black in Western Art, Volume III|last=Stoichita|first=Victor|date=|publisher=Harvard University Press|others=|year=2010|isbn=9780674052611|editor-last=Bindman|editor-first=David|edition=|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=226|chapter=The Image of the Black in Spanish Art: Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries|oclc=555658364|editor-last2=Gates, Jr|editor-first2=Henry Louis}}</ref>
It was the first painting to sell for more than £1,000,000. At the time of the painting's purchase by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in 1970 they considered it "among the most important acquisitions in the Museum's history".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 1971|title=Juan de Pareja by Diego Velázquez|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/metpublications/juan_de_pareja_by_diego_velazquez_the_metropolitan_museum_of_art_bulletin_v_29_no_10_part_ii_june_1971|journal=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin|volume=29|via=}}</ref> The painting is on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in [[New York City]].
==History== In 1649, as court painter to [[Philip IV of Spain]], Diego Velázquez was sent to Rome to purchase works of art for the [[Alcázar]] in Madrid. Velázquez brought with him Juan de Pareja, a [[Slavery in Spain|enslaved man]], who served as an assistant in the artist's workshop.<ref name="Metropolitan Museum of Art website">[http://www.metmuseum.org/collections/search-the-collections/437869 Metropolitan Museum of Art website]</ref> During his stay in Rome, Velázquez executed an oil painting of Juan de Pareja, which was displayed as part of a larger exhibition of paintings at the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]] on 19 March 1650. According to Antonio Palomino's biography of Velázquez, the painting "was generally applauded by all the painters from different countries, who said that the other pictures in the show were art but this one alone was 'truth'."<ref>{{cite book | author=Palomino, Antonio | title= El Museo pictórico y escala óptica | year=1724}}</ref>
Velázquez painted the portrait of [[Juan de Pareja]], who was of Moorish descent,<ref name="Metropolitan Museum of Art website"/> in his workshop, as an exercise in preparation for his official [[portrait of Pope Innocent X]]. The Pope, a ruddy-faced man who would be depicted in the bright pink and crimson robes of his office, presented a tricky study in both color and composition. Additionally, since he would be executing a portrait from life, Velázquez would be forced to work quickly while still capturing the essence of Innocent X's character. The ''Portrait of Juan de Pareja'' reflects Velázquez's exploration of the difficulties he would encounter in the Pope's portrait. To compensate for a restricted palette of colors, Velázquez adopted a loose, almost impressionistic style of brushwork to bring an intense vitality to his subject.
Juan de Pareja (circa 1610 – 1670) became an artist in his own right, and in 1654 he was freed by Velázquez.<ref name="Metropolitan Museum of Art website"/>
== Provenance and copies == The [[Provenance|painting's ownership]] between its first exhibition at the Pantheon in Rome in 1650 and the end of the eighteenth century is unknown. There is no record of the painting in Spain. The earliest record of the ownership of the painting was in essay written in 1765 by [[Francisco Preciado]], Director of the [[Real Academia Española|Royal Spanish Academy]] in Rome. He stated that the painting owned by Cardinal Trajano D'Acquaviva (1694-1747) who lived in Rome.
The painting then reappears in the record as part of the dukes of Baranello's collection in [[Naples]] sometime in the 1700s. It was recorded as part of the collection of [[William Hamilton (diplomat)|Sir William Hamilton]], the [[List of diplomats of the United Kingdom to the Two Sicilies#Envoys Extraordinary and Ministers Plenipotentiary to the Kingdom of Naples and.2For the Kingdom of Sicily|British Ambassador to the Kingdom of Naples]] from 1764 to 1798. The inventory of his residence in Naples, Palazzo Sessa, lists "a portrait of a Moresco slave by Velazquez." Hamilton sent the portrait and his other works of art to London for safekeeping, on board the ship [[HMS Foudroyant (1798)|HMS Fondroyant]] the [[flagship]] of [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Lord Nelson]], when he left Naples. Hamilton returned to England heavily in debt and the portrait was auctioned at [[Christie's]] in 1801. The auction catalogue listed the painting as Velazquez's "Portrait of a Moorish Slave, that was in his service, and became a great Painter". It sold for 39 guineas and disappeared from the record again.
It later surfaces in the collection of [[Jacob Pleydell-Bouverie, 2nd Earl of Radnor|Jacob Pleydell-Bouverie]], 2nd [[Earl of Radnor]] at [[Longford Castle]], [[Salisbury]]. In a catalogue of the Radnor family's collection, published in 1909, stated that the portrait was part of the collection by 1814 and may have been acquired in 1811. It remained in the ownership of the Radnor family for over 150 years until it was sold at Christie's in London for the record sum of £2,310,000<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2013/dec/01/archive-velazquez-scarred-price-tag|title=From the Observer archive: 29 November 1970: A Velázquez now forever scarred by its £2m price-tag|last=Gosling|first=Nigel|date=2013-12-01|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> (or 2,200,000 guineas<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.countrylife.co.uk/luxury/art-and-antiques/5-sales-made-christies-no-5-first-million-pound-picture-144183|title=The 5 sales which made Christie’s - No.5: The first million-pound picture - Country Life|date=2016-12-30|work=Country Life|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en-US}}</ref> or $5,544,000<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 5, 1971|title=Comment|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1971/06/05/comment-5350|journal=The New Yorker|volume=|pages=31|via=}}</ref>) on 27 November 1970. It was the first painting to sell for more than a £1,000,000, setting a new record for the price of paintings sold at auction.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2014/11/the-story-of-the-first-painting-to-sell-for-over-a-million-pounds/|title=The story of the first painting to sell for over a million pounds|last=Cork|first=Richard|date=2014-11-22|work=The Spectator|access-date=2017-10-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
[[Alec N. Wildenstein|Alec Wildenstein]] of [[Wildenstein & Company (art dealers)|Wildenstein & Company]] bid for the painting acting on behalf of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bzkFXl1ZkI8C&pg=PA183&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Landscape with Figures: A History of Art Dealing in the United States|last=Goldstein|first=Malcolm|date=2000-11-30|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198031277|language=en}}</ref> The painting was acquired by the Museum in 1971, principally with through from the [[Isaac Dudley Fletcher|Fletcher Fund]], with an understanding the two million dollars would be paid back over time with income generated from the [[Jacob S. Rogers|Rogers Fund]], Fletcher Fund and other funds "restricted to buying funds".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dItWAJxHT2MC&pg=PA264&dq=%22fletcher+fund%22+juan+pareja&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiEyd-E_fDWAhWCnBoKHd1ZAjUQ6AEISTAF#v=onepage&q=%22fletcher%20fund%22%20juan%20pareja&f=false|title=Making the Mummies Dance: Inside The Metropolitan Museum Of Art|last=Hoving|first=Thomas|date=1994-02-15|publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=|isbn=9780671880750|location=|pages=264|language=en}}</ref> The painting is considered one of the "most important acquisitions in the Museum's history". Theodore Rousseau, when Curator-in-Chief of the Museum, stated that the painting was "one of the finest works of art to come on the market in our time."<ref name=":0" />
The finest and best-known copy belongs to the [[Hispanic Society of America]], New York.<ref name=":0" /> The Hispanic Society's copy is believed to have been painted from the original while it was in the collection of the earl of Radnor at Longford Castle.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/pubs/bulletins/1/pdf/3258774.pdf.bannered.pdf|title=A Note on the Dimensions of Juan de Pareja|last=von Sonnenburg|first=Hubert|date=Winter 1993–94|website=|publisher=The Metropolitian Museum of Art|journal=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin}}</ref> Some believe Hispanic Society copy was painted by the sitter himself, Juan de Pareja.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/437869|title=Juan de Pareja by Velázquez (Diego Rodríguez de Silva y Velázquez) (1606–1670) {{!}} Catalogue Entry {{!}} The Picture's Owners; Copies|last=|first=|date=|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-14}}</ref>
==Legacy and influence== The portrait inspired the famous 1965 novel ''[[I, Juan de Pareja]]'' by [[Elizabeth Borton de Treviño]]. The novel was awarded the children's literary prize the [[Newbery Medal]] in 1966.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fracchia|first=Carmen|last2=Macartney|first2=Hilary|date=2012-06-01|title=The Fall into Oblivion of the Works of the Slave Painter Juan de Pareja|url=http://eprints.gla.ac.uk/68437/1/68437.pdf|journal=Art in Translation|volume=4|issue=2|pages=163–183|doi=10.2752/175613112X13309377913043|via=}}</ref>
Velazquez's painting reinterpreted by surrealist painter [[Salvador Dalí|Salvador Dali]] in his 1960 work ''Portrait of Juan de Pareja, the Assistant to Velázquez'' which is in the collection of the [[Minneapolis Institute of Art]]''.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://collections.artsmia.org/art/3291/portrait-of-juan-de-pareja-the-assistant-to-velazquez-salvador-dali|title=Portrait of Juan de Pareja, the Assistant to Velázquez, Salvador Dali; Depicted: Juan de Pareja|last=|first=|date=|website=Minneapolis Institute of Art|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-10}}</ref> French-[[Senegal]]ese artist [[Iba N'Diaye]] restaged the Velazquez portrait in his 1985-86 painting ''Juan de Pareja agresse par les chiens (Juan de Pareja menaced by dogs)'' .<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=77fWBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA49|title=Art History and Fetishism Abroad: Global Shiftings in Media and Methods|last=Genge|first=Gabriele|last2=Stercken|first2=Angela|date=2014|publisher=transcript Verlag|year=|isbn=9783839424117|location=|pages=49|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yjbQnqI5HR0C&pg=PA164&dq=%22%22juan+de+pareja+agresse+par+les+chiens%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiihcSS0_DWAhWCwxoKHStlDegQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=%22%22juan%20de%20pareja%20agresse%20par%20les%20chiens%22&f=false|title=The Idea of Africa|last=Mudimbe|first=V. Y.|date=1994|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=9780852552346|language=en}}</ref>
A central theme of the 2012 play ''[[Disgraced]]'' by [[Ayad Akhtar]] is a painting of the protagonist, a South Asian Muslim man, as painted by his white wife in the style of the ''Portrait of Juan de Pareja''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=MQ4XDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA83&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=juan&f=false|title=South Asian Racialization and Belonging after 9/11: Masks of Threat|last=Basu|first=Lopamudra|date=2016-05-26|publisher=Lexington Books|year=|isbn=9781498512534|editor-last=De|editor-first=Aparajita|location=|pages=83–88|language=en|chapter=Between Performativity and Representation}}</ref>
==See also== [[Representation of slavery in European art]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/63259/rec/2 ''Velázquez ''], exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on this portrait (see index)
{{Diego Velázquez}}
[[Category:1650s in Spain]] [[Category:1650s paintings]] [[Category:Velazquez portraits in Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Portraits of men|Pareja]] [[Category:Slavery in art]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Van Gogh - Portrait of Pere Tanguy 1887-8.JPG | image_size = 300 px | title = ''Portrait of Père Tanguy'', final version | artist = [[Vincent van Gogh]] | year = 1887 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | catalogue = F363 | height_metric =65.0 | width_metric =51.0 | height_imperial =25.6 | width_imperial =20.0 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Paris]] | museum = [[Musée Rodin]] }}
'''''Portrait of Père Tanguy''''', painted by [[Vincent van Gogh]] in 1887, is one of his three paintings of Julien Tanguy. The three works demonstrate a progression in van Gogh's artistic style after his arrival in Paris. The first is somber, and formed from a simple composition. The second introduces [[Japonaiserie (Van Gogh)|van Gogh's Japanese prints]]. The last and most advanced in style, skill and color integrates [[Japanese art|Japanese]], [[Impressionism|Impressionist]], and other influences on the Parisian artist community. This painting conveys a sense of serenity that van Gogh seeks for himself. This last painting of Tanguy is in the [[Musée Rodin]], Paris.
==Van Gogh in Paris== In 1886 van Gogh left the [[Netherlands]] never to return. He moved to Paris to live with his brother [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]], a Parisian art dealer. Vincent entered Paris as a shy, somber man. While his personality would never change, he emerged artistically into what one critic described as a "singing bird".<ref name="Wallace"/> Although van Gogh had been influenced by great masters in the Netherlands, coming to Paris meant that he was exposed to Impressionists, [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolists]], [[Pointillism|Pointillists]], and Japanese art (''see [[Japonism]]''). His circle of friends included [[Camille Pissarro]], [[Henri Toulouse-Lautrec]], [[Paul Gauguin]], [[Émile Bernard (painter)|Émile Bernard]], [[Paul Signac]], and others. The works of the Japanese [[ukiyo-e]] artists [[Hiroshige]] and [[Hokusai]] greatly influenced van Gogh, both for the subject matter and the style of flat patterns of colors without shadow. In the two years from 1886 through 1888 he spent working in Paris, van Gogh explored the various genres, creating his own unique style.<ref name="Wallace">{{cite book | title=The World of Van Gogh (1853-1890) | author=Wallace, R | editor=Editors of Time-Life Books | publisher=Time-Life Books | location=Alexandria, VA, USA | year=1969 | pages=40, 69 | url= }}</ref>
==The painting== The brightly colored painting and confident subject represent a shift in Vincent's attitude.<ref name="Meier"/><ref name="Maurer"/> Van Gogh called his use of bright colors "gymnastics" that through experimentation created great depth, harmony and balance in his work.<ref name="Maurer"/><ref name="Finlay"/> The painting contains a background of van Gogh's Japanese prints that were sold at Tanguy's shop.<ref name="Maurer"/> On top of Tanguy's hat is [[Mount Fuji]];<ref name="Maurer"/><ref name="Finlay"/> [[Kabuki]] actors share the wall with cherry trees in bloom.<ref name="Finlay"/>
The Japanese paintings represent van Gogh's search for serenity, which he describes in a letter to his sister during this period, "Having as much of this serenity as possible, even though one knows little – nothing – for certain, is perhaps a better remedy for all diseases than all the things that are sold at the chemist's shop."<ref name="Meier"/><ref name="Maurer">{{cite book | title=The pursuit of spiritual wisdom: the thought and art of Vincent van Gogh and Paul Gauguin | author=Maurer, N | publisher=Associated University Presses | location=Cranbury | year=1999 | origyear=1998 | pages=55, 59 | isbn=0-8386-3749-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wf_PoXKhggkC&pg=PA55 }}</ref> In an effort to capture serenity in his painting, Van Gogh paints Tanguy with a calm, contemplative nature. Historian of Symbolism Naomi Maurer describes him as having the "iconic tranquility of Buddha."<ref name="Maurer"/>
Van Gogh died in 1890 and Tanguy four years after. Following Tanguy's death, his daughter sold the ''Portrait of Père Tanguy'' to sculptor [[Auguste Rodin]].<ref name="Strieter">{{cite book | title=Nineteenth-Century European Art: A Topical Dictionary | author=Strieter, T | publisher=Greenwood Press | location=Westport, CT, USA | year=1999 | pages=174–175 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lDr7Tbk__1kC&pg=PA174 | isbn=0-313-29898-X}}</ref> The ''Portrait of Père Tanguy,'' previously in Rodin's personal collection, is in the permanent collection at [[Musée Rodin]] in Paris.<ref name="Rodin">{{cite web |url=http://www.musee-rodin.fr/welcome.htm |title=Rodin as a Collector (Extract from the work Rodin - Le musée et ses collections, published by Scala, Paris, 1996) |author= |date= |work=Collections |publisher=Musée Rodin |accessdate=March 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110406115207/http://www.musee-rodin.fr/welcome.htm |archivedate=April 6, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Julien Tanguy== Julien François Tanguy (1825 [[Plédran]] - 1894 Paris) was a paint grinder who sold art supplies and was also an art dealer,<ref name="Gay"/> one of the first to offer van Gogh's paintings for sale.<ref name="Leeuw">{{cite book | title=The letters of Vincent Van Gogh | author=Leeuw, R | publisher=Penguin Group | location=London and other locations | origyear=1996 | year=1997 | page=329 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SyX5lfrof6oC&pg=PA329 }}</ref> His jovial demeanor and enthusiasm for artistry and artists made his shop one of the most favored art supply shops in Paris, and he was nicknamed ''Père'' ("Father") Tanguy.<ref name="Gay"/> Maurer calls Tanguy a father figure who shared his food and money with artists and showed their paintings with pride.<ref name="Maurer"/>
Tanguy took paintings as payment for paints,<ref name="Maurer"/><ref name="Gay"/> which [[Émile Bernard (painter)|Émile Bernard]] said made entering his shop in [[Montmartre]], full of Impressionist paintings, like "visiting a museum".<ref name="Finlay"/> In comparison to her husband, Tanguy's wife was less cooperative and more concerned with clientele paying outstanding charges.<ref name="Finlay"/> When Tanguy died, his friends staged an auction for his widow.<ref name="Gay">{{cite book | title=Pleasure Wars | author=Gay, P | publisher=W. W. Norton and Company | location=New York | origyear=1998 | year=1999 | page=143 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rmZhMjac60IC&pg=PA143| isbn=0-393-31827-3}}</ref>
[[Octave Mirbeau]] wrote a notice about him in ''[[L'Écho de Paris]]'' on 13 February 1894.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k8002580 |work= L'Écho de Paris|title=Le Père Tanguy|date=13 February 1894|accessdate=29 November 2012|language=French}}</ref>
==Three ''Portraits of Julien Tanguy''== Van Gogh painted three portraits of Julien (Père) Tanguy.
[[File:Van Gogh - Bildnis Père Tanguy.jpeg|thumb|''Portrait of Père Tanguy'', winter 1886/87. (47x38.5cm) (F263)]] In winter 1886/87 van Gogh painted his first portrait of Tanguy.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=9783836541220|title=Vincent van Gogh: The Complete Paintings|first1=Ingo|last1=Walther|first2=Rainer|last2=Metzger|publisher=Taschen|page=204}}</ref> It is mostly brown, with a touch of red on his lips and a green on his apron. Writer [[Victoria Finlay]] describes him as looking more like a workman than an art dealer.<ref name="Finlay">{{cite book | title=Color: A Natural History of the Palette | author=Finlay, V | publisher=Random House Trade Paperbacks | location=New York and Toronto | year=2002 | page=20 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X0iTdXt1XoMC&pg=PA20| isbn=0-8129-7142-6 }}</ref>
[[File:Van Gogh - Bildnis Père Tanguy1.jpeg|thumb|''Portrait of Père Tanguy'', The second painting of Père Tanguy by Vincent van Gogh (65 cm x 51 cm) (F364)]] In 1887, van Gogh began to experiment with brighter colors, such as red against green and orange against blue.<ref name="Finlay"/> The other two paintings show him sitting in front of a colorful wall of Japanese prints.<ref name="Finlay"/> The second to the right was painted by van Gogh in one thirty-minute sitting,<ref name="Meier"/> and Tanguy kept the original version of the painting.<ref name="Meier">{{cite book | title=Vincent Van Gogh: A Biography | author=Meier-Graefe, J | publisher=Dover Publications | location=Mineola, NY, USA | year=1987 | origyear=London: Michael Joseph, Ltd. 1936 | pages=56–57 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iw7R8k5GfgMC&pg=PA56 | postscript=There are other pages that also provide background about van Gogh's evolution since coming to Paris, such as pages 68, 77 }}</ref><ref name="Finlay"/> Actor [[Edward G. Robinson]] and his wife Gladys Lloyd Robinson, a painter, owned the painting,<ref>{{cite book | title=Looking Back to the Future: Essays on Art, Life and Death | first1=G | last1=Pollock | first2=P | last2=Florence | publisher=G + B Arts International | location= | year=2001 | page=291 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WYcUakyueooC&pg=PA291 | isbn=90-5701-122-0}}</ref> which they sold to Greek shipping tycoon [[Stavros Niarchos]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gill | first1=W |date=November 2, 1962 |title=Strange Story of Walter Chrysler Jr. Art Scandal |journal=Life Magazine | volume=53 | issue=18 | pages=80–83 | publisher=Time, Inc. | doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n0oEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA80 | accessdate=March 19, 2011 | postscript=The painting owned by [[Stavros Niarchos]], the [[Greece|Greek]] shipping magnate, is noted by the tree bark to the left of his face, the flower just below the tree and the manner in which his face, shirt and jacket were painted.}}</ref>
The second, more advanced painting with Japanese prints is held in the [[Musée Rodin]] in Paris.<ref name="Meier"/><ref name="Finlay"/>

revision.text:
[[File:Paolo Monti - Servizio fotografico (Italia, 1965) - BEIC 6343298.jpg|thumb|Sculpture by [[Giò Pomodoro]] for the 9th Quadriennale nazionale d'arte of Rome. Photo by [[Paolo Monti]].]]
The '''Rome Quadriennale''' ([[Italian language|Italian]]: ''Quadriennale di Roma'', also called in English the ''Rome Quadrennial'') is a [[Foundation (nonprofit organization)|foundation]] for the promotion of contemporary [[Italian art]].
Its name derives from the four-yearly exhibitions it is required to host by its constitution. It is based in [[Rome]] in the monumental complex of Villa Carpegna.
==Exhibitions== All the Rome Quadriennale main exhibitions held at its historical site, the [[Palazzo delle Esposizioni]] of [[Rome]], except where indicated.
*I Quadriennale, January - June 1931. *II Quadriennale, February - July 1935.<ref>Claudia Lazzaro, Roger J. Crum Donatello Among The Blackshirts: History And Modernity In The ... 2005- Page 275 "Mario Mascarin, "La grande pitiée de l'art en Italie," Monde, 22 March 1935. Written two months before the opening, and perhaps in response to the Rome Quadriennale, this article on contemporary art under Fascism knowingly anticipated the .."</ref> *III Quadriennale, February - July 1939. *IV Quadriennale, May - July 1943. *V Quadriennale, March - May 1948. *VI Quadriennale, December 1951 - April 1952. *VII Quadriennale, November 1955 - 1956. *VIII Quadriennale, December 1959 - April 1960. *IX Quadriennale, October 1965 - March 1966. *X Quadriennale, Five exhibitions: ** November - December 1972. ** February - March 1973. ** May - June 1973. ** March - April 1975. ** June - July 1977. *XI Quadriennale, [[Palazzo dei Congressi]], [[Esposizione Universale Roma|EUR complex]], [[Rome]], May - August 1986. *XII Quadriennale, two exhibitions: ** July - September 1992. ** [[Palazzo delle Esposizioni]] and the Ala Mazzoniana of the [[Roma Termini railway station]], September - November 1996. *1999. XIII Quadriennale, [[Palazzo delle Esposizioni]], June - September 1999. *XIV Quadriennale three exhibitions: ** [[Royal Palace (Naples)|Palazzo Reale]], [[Naples]], November 2003 - January 2004. ** Palazzo della Promotrice delle Belle Arti, [[Turin]], January - March 2004. ** [[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna]], [[Rome]], March - May 2005. *[[15th Rome Quadriennale|XV Quadriennale]], June - September 2008.<ref>[http://english.palazzoesposizioni.it/canale.asp?id=256 15th Rome Quadrennial]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} at [[Palazzo delle Esposizioni]] official website.</ref>
==See also== *[[Venice Biennale]] *[[Rome Film Festival]]
==Notes and references== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.quadriennalediroma.org/?lang=en '''Fondazione La Quadriennale di Roma''' Official Website]
